questions.clue: This ancient civilization, known for its pyramids and pharaohs, was centered around the Nile River.

This ancient Mesopotamian civilization developed cuneiform, one of the earliest known writing systems.
The civilization known for its advanced mathematics and astronomy, which rose in the Yucatan Peninsula around 2000 BC.
This civilization, centered in the Andes mountains, was conquered by Francisco Pizarro in the 16th century.
This simple machine consisting of a wheel with a rope around it is used to lift heavy objects.
The non-stick coating on many frying pans is made from this polymer, known for its high melting point and resistance to sticking.
This household item uses Fleming's left-hand rule to convert electrical energy into motion, found in fans and blenders.
This common kitchen appliance uses a magnetron to heat food by agitating water molecules.
This scientific principle explains why a straw in a glass of water appears bent at the surface, due to light traveling at different speeds.
This villain from 'Harry Potter' is known for his lack of a nose and his quest for immortality.
In 'The Lion, the Witch, and the Wardrobe', she turns Narnia into a perpetual winter.
Obsessed with a white whale, this captain from 'Moby-Dick' meets a tragic fate.
He's the chilling antagonist in 'Heart of Darkness' who is often described as a demigod by his followers.
This character from 'Paradise Lost' famously declares, 'Better to reign in Hell, than serve in Heaven.'
This British band, known as the 'Fab Four,' dominated the music scene in the 1960s.
This 'Queen of Disco' lit up the 1970s with hits like 'Last Dance' and 'Hot Stuff.'
MTV launched in 1981 with a song by this band, whose name implies a futuristic broadcast.
Kurt Cobain led this grunge band that rose to fame in the early 1990s with the album 'Nevermind.'
This artist, known for 'FutureSex/LoveSounds,' was a member of *NSYNC before going solo in the 2000s.
She was the first woman to fly solo across the Atlantic Ocean in 1932.
This British monarch had the longest reign before Queen Elizabeth II surpassed her in 2015.
Known as 'The Maid of Orléans,' she led French forces to victory in the Hundred Years' War before being burned at the stake.
This Polish and naturalized-French physicist was the first woman to win a Nobel Prize and the only one to win in two different sciences.
A leading figure of the women's suffrage movement, she co-founded the National Woman's Party and played a major role in the passage of the 19th Amendment.

final.clue: In 1839, Sir John Herschel coined this term for a type of drawing that used light-sensitive paper, popularized later by architects & engineers.
